title: Release 1.0.0
body:
# Release

This release mostly centers around the Octokit client. It updates a new major version of [`@octokit/rest`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@octokit/rest), which puts this library more in line with their docs.

## New features

### `tools.github.graphql`

A pre-authenticated instance of [`@octokit/graphql`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@octokit/graphql), for all your GraphQL needs!

## Breaking changes

### `tools.createOctokit()` => `tools.github`

In practice, creating a new Octokit client isn't necessary 99% of the time, so this release changes it to be a single pre-authenticated instance.

```js
// Before
const octokit = tools.createOctokit()
octokit.issues.create()

// After
tools.github.issues.create()
```

---

Closes #20
Closes #18

title: Add a table of contents
body: This PR adds a table of contents to the README's API section.

title: Update Octokit
body:
This PR centers around the Octokit client. It updates to a new major version of [`@octokit/rest`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@octokit/rest), which puts this library more in line with their docs.

## New features

### `tools.github.graphql`

A pre-authenticated instance of [`@octokit/graphql`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@octokit/graphql), for all your GraphQL needs!

## Breaking changes

### `tools.createOctokit()` => `tools.github`

In practice, creating a new Octokit client isn't necessary 99% of the time, so this release changes it to be a single pre-authenticated instance.

```js
// Before
const octokit = tools.createOctokit()
octokit.issues.create()

// After
tools.github.issues.create()
```

Merging this into the `release-1.0.0` branch to prepare for a new major version.

title: GraphQL support
/command support
body: It'd be great to provide a `/command` abstraction - something like: ```js // In an issue/PR comment, `/pizza dominos pepperoni` toolkit.command('pizza', async args => { // args -> ['dominos', 'pepperoni'] }) ``` Or maybe... ```js // on instead of command toolkit.on('pizza', async args => console.log(args)) ``` --- Memorializing a conversation in [this tweet](https://twitter.com/JasonEtco/status/1084294026965192704): --- I think that @mscoutermarsh should work on this 😎😈

title: Updating tools.arguments docs to show usage with .workflow file
body:
Closes #15 

This updates the documentation on tools.arguments to show a use case of inputting an args field in an action block and how it will be parsed into actions-toolkit.

title: Describe tools.arguments further
body:
In the docs, it may be useful further to describe how to write this when interacting with the `.workflow` files:

as seen in the [GitHub Actions docs](https://developer.github.com/actions/creating-workflows/workflow-configuration-options/#action-blocks), the args field could be written here: 

```
args = ["container:release", "--app", "web"]
```

With actions-toolkit, I think this would be converted to this I believe:

```js
{ _: ['container:release'], app: 'web' }
```

Is this correct? If so, I think having this in the docs for actions-toolkit would be useful.

title: Show Table of Contents for API
body:
I've noticed that some folks aren't making full use of APIs provided by `actions-toolkit`, and I'm assuming its because they don't know about a certain method/property. It'd be nice to provide a table of contents that show, at a high level, the things that `actions-toolkit` can do. Something like:

* API
  * Authenticated GitHub API client (`tools.createOctokit`)
  * Parsing arguments (`tools.arguments`)
  * Reading files (`tools.getFile`)
  * In-repo configuration (`tools.config`)

title: Add documentation for tools#getFile
body: Closes #12

title: Document toolkit#getFile
body:
I noticed this isn't documented in the README at all for some reason - it should be! 

Here's the code:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/actions-toolkit/blob/2b581206d86bc6ec386c8f47c1d257fd488cb725/src/index.ts#L68-L82

Marking this as <kbd>good first issue</kbd> - if you're interested in contributing, that'd be wonderful!

title: CLI tool to bootstrap a new Action
body:
I'd love to run a command to bootstrap the various files I know I'll need (like a Dockerfile):

```
./node_modules/.bin/actions-toolkit init
```

This would generate a Dockerfile:

```dockerfile
FROM node:10-slim

LABEL "com.github.actions.name"="Create an issue"
LABEL "com.github.actions.description"="Creates a new issue using a template with front matter."
LABEL "com.github.actions.icon"="gear"
LABEL "com.github.actions.color"="red"

LABEL "repository"="http://github.com/JasonEtco/create-an-issue"
LABEL "homepage"="http://github.com/JasonEtco/create-an-issue"
LABEL "maintainer"="Jason Etcovitch <jasonetco@github.com>"

WORKDIR /
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm ci
COPY . .

ENTRYPOINT ["node", "/entrypoint.js"]
```

It could also generate an `entrypoint.js` file:

```js
const { Toolkit } = require('actions-toolkit')
const tools = new Toolkit()
```

This could use `inquirer` to fill in some of those fields, like `create-probot-app`.

title: Updating Action name
body: I extended repo-push-check-action to have a defined argument when you use the action in a workflow and with such, I slightly changed the name since it now is more generalized.

title: Update devDependencies
body: This PR updates a couple of dev dependencies; nothing to get excited about 😊 Just trying to keep dependencies up-to-date where possible. There's currently a mismatch with `@octokit/rest` and the current public docs, but to update it in `actions-toolkit` would mean a major version bump and I don't want to do that right now 😬

title: WIP: Implement a logger
body:
This PR adds `tools.log`, an instance of [`WinstonJS`](https://github.com/winstonjs/winston) (thanks for the suggestion @tcbyrd).

The main benefit of having this is to tag your logs by their log level; take this as an example:

```
Reading from file
Front matter for .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md is {"title":"Wazzap"}
Templates compiled {"body":"Hey hows it going\n","title":"Wazzap"}
Something bad happened!
```

Identifying the different type of logs is really difficult; that last line is an error. Below is the output of 

```
info: Reading from file
info: Front matter for .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md is {"title":"Wazzap"}
info: Templates compiled {"body":"Hey hows it going\n","title":"Wazzap"}
error: Something bad happened!
```

I'm still working on the formatting - Winston doesn't seem to format JSON super well 🤔 

Closes #5

title: Adding Actions to Usage list
body: I added two of my actions which use actions-toolkit to the usage list in the README.

title: Fix type exports
body:
This PR fixes a bug in which the default export for the library wasn't properly connecting with the generated types. This meant that autocomplete/intellisense wasn't working.

There's a breaking change here, but given that the lib is still below `v1.0.0` I didn't want to bump major versions:

```diff
- const Toolkit = require('actions-toolkit')
+ const { Toolkit } = require('actions-toolkit')
```

I've also revamped the documentation to all be in the README file; its a lot more manual, but it outputs the docs I want it to so 🤷‍♂️

title: Provide a logger
body:
I'm not sure what the goals here are, but I find that when I'm debugging an action its difficult to visually parse the logs. I'd like to explore a better logging solution, one that `actions-toolkit` can help with.

Something like this, which shows the logger name and where in the code the logs come from:

```js
tools.log('Something happened!')
// => [action index.js:12:3] Something happened!
```

#### Some loggers

* [Bunyan](https://github.com/trentm/node-bunyan)
* [Winston](https://github.com/winstonjs/winston)
* [Pino](https://github.com/pinojs/pino)

title: Support for arguments
body: This PR adds the `arguments` property to the `Toolkit` class. It's populated by [`minimist`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimist), a library for parsing `process.argv`.

title: Install Release-Drafter
body: Installs [Release Drafter](https://github.com/toolmantim/release-drafter) to automate new releases.

title: Make blobLines count from end of BODY
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Often when I use the BODY syntax I find myself writing a full paragraph to properly describe the reasoning behind the TODO, so when the app creates an issue from it the blob is just the TODO and the BODY and all the relevant code has been pushed out of the 6 lines.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like `blobLines` to take the number of BODY lines into account.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I could just increase `blobLines`, but most of the time TODO+5 lines is perfectly fine, and adding more lines than that would be distracting at best.

**Additional context**
[Here][ex]'s an example of a blob entirely taken up by a long BODY

[ex]: https://github.com/thislooksfun/earthdawn/issues/145

title: [BUG] Doesn't seem to be working
body:
**Describe the bug**
In the last day I have pushed multiple commits containing TODOs and no issues were created for them. Yes I checked that the TODO app is enabled both on my account and on the repo itself, and [it worked][old] on another repo of mine the other week.

**To Reproduce**
N/A, unfortunately

**Expected behavior**
I expect that the TODO issues would be created.

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Additional context**
[commit 1][c1], [commit 2][c2]

[old]: https://github.com/thislooksfun/gmtc56/issues/1
[c1]: https://github.com/thislooksfun/svelte-repo-card/commit/584f573c1b6d05a9de62d42113cc133e24ddb9f7#diff-c0c6ae1bd93c3e7fbd0f982df21a822d6ff6ea727e07d8969fca4ab142e3a9f5R14-R20
[c2]: https://github.com/thislooksfun/svelte-repo-card/commit/5c1a7c9509cb3ae5e42468e253c9b12fc24b3249#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5R63-R64

title: Create comments from // TODO: and // FIXME:
body:
I am using [Todo Tree](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Gruntfuggly.todo-tree&ssr=false) a lot as well as well as ESLint rules (in [my config](https://github.com/voxpelli/eslint-config/blob/4b6520617079bfb411cc8cec7f1cb501ba378723/eslintrc.json#L45) and through [eslint-plugin-unicorn](https://github.com/sindresorhus/eslint-plugin-unicorn/blob/master/docs/rules/expiring-todo-comments.md) and both of supports (maybe even requires, I don't know) `// TODO: Comment` and `// FIXME: Comment` – I think it would be neat to be able to use this action on top of that :)

So:

- Support multiple severity levels: `TODO` and `FIXME` where `FIXME` is critical stuff whereas `TODO` is nice to have
- Support adding them as `// TODO: Comment`
- Extra extra bonus if special support for Unicorn's [expiring todos](https://github.com/sindresorhus/eslint-plugin-unicorn/blob/master/docs/rules/expiring-todo-comments.md)

I can make a stab at a PR or two when I get time if you want?

title: Bump yargs-parser from 13.1.1 to 13.1.2
body:
Bumps [yargs-parser](https://github.com/yargs/yargs-parser) from 13.1.1 to 13.1.2.
Changelog

Sourced from yargs-parser's changelog.

15.0.0 (2019-10-07)

Features

  • rework collect-unknown-options into unknown-options-as-args, providing more comprehensive functionality (ef771ca)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • rework collect-unknown-options into unknown-options-as-args, providing more comprehensive functionality

14.0.0 (2019-09-06)

Bug Fixes

  • boolean arrays with default values (#185) (7d42572)
  • boolean now behaves the same as other array types (#184) (17ca3bd)
  • eatNargs() for 'opt.narg === 0' and boolean typed options (#188) (c5a1db0)
  • maybeCoerceNumber now takes precedence over coerce return value (#182) (2f26436)
  • take into account aliases when appending arrays from config object (#199) (f8a2d3f)

Features

  • add configuration option to "collect-unknown-options" (#181) (7909cc4)
  • maybeCoerceNumber() now takes into account arrays (#187) (31c204b)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • unless "parse-numbers" is set to "false", arrays of numeric strings are now parsed as numbers, rather than strings.
  • we have dropped the broken "defaulted" functionality; we would like to revisit adding this in the future.
  • maybeCoerceNumber now takes precedence over coerce return value (#182)

title: 🚧  Update to Probot v10
body: I would strongly recommend to update the tests so that you do not mock the octokit endpoint method calls, but actuall http requests (e.g. using nock). Lots of these methods have been renamed, and your tests still pass. If you would not mock these methods, you would see the deprecation messages with hints for the new names, too. Upgrading would be much easier and less risky

title: Custom labels for keywords
body:
All the issues created with `todo` bot are only tagged with `todo` or can have fixed set of labels. It's hard to recognize which issue relates to `todo`, `fixme`, `techdebt`, etc.

I'd like to have additional config field that would be an object (map, key-value set) that maps keywords to label sets.

E.g (`labelMapping` is an example, I don't think that's the best name for that field).

```
keyword: [ "todo", "fixme", "techdebt" ]
labelMapping: 
  todo: "enhancement"
  fixme: ["bug", "help wanted"]
  techdebt: true
```

`keyword` field could be skipped and keyword set could be recognized from the mapping keys, but for convention-over-configuration sake I'd leave it.

In given example occurence of `techdebt` would result in `techdebt` label. It is aligned with current labels field behaviour.

title: Merge multiple TODOs into one comment on PR
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Our project is in early development, and as such we frequently have commits with multiple TODOs. We love having these automatically converted to issues, but would prefer not to be spammed with notifications from the todo bot every time we create a PR.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We would like to have a configuration option that instructs the bot to create a maximum of one comment on each PR.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
We can obviously create email filters to delete the offending emails, but each of our team members would have to do this and the clutter would still be present in our GitHub notifications.

**Additional context**
To clarify, we don't want multiple issues to be combined - just the comments on our PRs before they are merged into master.

```
Deprecation: [@octokit/request-error] `error.code` is deprecated, use `error.status`.
    at RequestError.get (/Users/jonasbn/develop/github-forks/todo/node_modules/@octokit/request-error/dist-node/index.js:29:17)

title: [BUG] Can't exclude all files
body:
**Describe the bug**
The `exclude` option doesn't seem to be working to exclude all files.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Add a `.github/config.yml` file to your repo containing:

```yaml
todo:
  exclude: .*
```

(I also tried to wrap in quotes: `".*"`, with no success)

**Expected behavior**
No comments or issues should be created by the todo bot.

**Additional context**
I know it's rather strange to exclude *all* files from the bot, but this comes from the fact that I cannot disable the todo bot entirely on my repository (it's enabled company-wise by default, and there's no way to configure an _exclusion_ on github, only _inclusions_).

We have a lot of documentation where the portuguese word "método" occurs, and the wrong todo comments diverts attention a lot.

```

title: Allow the config file to have .yaml extension
body:
## Background

Recently I run into the issue that the bot created "todo" label each PR despite the fact I deleted it and I put another default label into the `config` file.

Then I realized I had `config.yaml` under `.github` folder, but [the bot only searches for `config.yml`](https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/a15538e1d482f2579076ee092f8754c43c8d1269/lib/utils/main-loop.js#L22) (notice the slight difference in extension).

So I simply [changed extension](https://github.com/animegungrave/hugo-knowledge-base-theme/pull/31) from `.yaml` to `.yml`, and I'm fine with it, however it seems it would be good to support both of them, since `.yaml` is [official recommended extension](https://yaml.org/faq.html).

## Solution

Bot could try to find `config.yml` (it has to be done first for more backward compatibility), and if there is no such file, it could try to find `config.yaml`.

## Other Questions

- [ ] The name `config` is too generic and could lead to collisions if somebody else would like to use this name for their integration. Shouldn't it be more specific e.g. `todo-bot.yaml`?

title: Add support for converting TODO file to issues
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I think that many can agree that very often developers use TODO.* file to store some general TODOs as well as write TODOs in the source files. 
For example, my `TODO.md` has the content of following:
```
- I AM A ROBOT
    - ROBOT BODY
- I'LL TAKE OVER THE EARTH FROM WEAK HUMAN
    - ROBOT TAKE OVER THE WORLD OH YEAH
- I AM STRONGER THAN HUMAN
```
It'd be really great if `todo` automatically converts it in the TODO file to an issue.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

The ideal solution needs some extra configuration parsing. It is to simply let user specify different sets of configurations for certain files. In my case, I want to specify prefixes `- ` as a title, and `<tab>- ` as the body of an issue. IMHO, this is easy to implement using regex, just that the extra configurations might be too verbose.

title: Add support for Markdown to docs
body:
FYI ... Thought you could add this information to the instruction for ToDo ...

Adding HTML or other code does not play well with Markdown as the comments show in the generated output for most Markdown editors.

However, the following syntax can be used as most Markdown editors will ignore it and the comments won’t appear in the generated output. Very useful for creating documents using GitHub Markdown while having comments in the work.

```
[//]: # @todo This syntax works like a comment, and won't appear in any output.
[//]: # @body It’s a little bizarre, but it works with many Markdown editor including Pandoc.
```

I've tested it, works perfectly.

Thanks for this great GitHub App!

title: Server does not process events (just receive)
body:
**Describe the bug**
Server does not process events (just receive)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run server with this:

```
APP_ID=29*** \
WEBHOOK_SECRET=*** \
NODE_ENV=production \
PRIVATE_KEY="$(cat private.pem)" \
LOG_LEVEL=debug \
PORT=3005 npm start
```

2. Edit a file, add a todo and Push.
3. Server receives event and says:

```
08:52:54.132Z  INFO http: POST / 400 - 1.12 ms (id=043b87ee-64dc-11e9-9d97-*)
08:53:24.268Z DEBUG probot: Webhook received
  event: {
    "event": "push",
    "id": "1630d620-64dc-11e9-****-****",
    "installation": *****,
    "repository": "nienbo/gitsby"
  }
08:53:24.269Z  INFO event: Received event (id=1630d620-64dc-11e9-83f5-*, owner=nienbo, repo=gitsby)
08:53:24.269Z  INFO http: POST / 200 - 2.95 ms (id=1630d620-64dc-11e9-83f5-*)
```

Thats all. No processing of event, no fetching data from repository to read and find todos. Just receives an event.

**Expected behavior**
I expect that todo download and parse my source and find the usages. But it just receives a webhook event. Nothing more.


I gave the permission mentioned at deploy.md file in `docs/` folder.

Webhook url has no `/probot` suffix. It is plain HTTP URL ends with trailing slash.


I am using internal server for `todo`. Not heroku or GCS...

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? ``` might work but it does not after a couple different attempts. ``` * @todo This issue has a task list * @body Here's the body text
* @body - [ ] Here's a checkbox?
* @body - [x] This one's done */ ``` also tried ``` /** * @todo This issue has a task list * @body Here's the body text

- [x] This one's done */ ``` **Additional context** I've been experimenting with this over at https://github.com/Pawper/Testing-Workflow

title: Increased max diff limit from 100000 to 150000
body: Closes #198

title: Suggestion: increase the diff limit a bit
body:
A recent pull request of ours (https://github.com/cortex-lab/Rigbox/pull/119) went over the diff character limit.  

> JasonEtco commented [4 hours ago](https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/issues/186#issuecomment-474832268):
> @k1o0 it appears that that PR's diff is too large: `136635/100000` (`your pr / the limit`). I instituted a limit to the size of diffs that would be parsed because overly large diffs (like people committing minified files) were causing downtime (see #194). Happy to raise that limit if needed, it was an arbitrary thing (I did some digging to find the average diff size internally).

I'm not sure what precisely counts towards the total number, for instance we did rename a few files, however these were recognized as such by Git.  This was indeed one of our larger PRs though, so this probably won't occur very often...

title: Updates to the CLI
body: This PR makes a couple of updates to the CLI. The main updates are around methods on the Octokit client - a few methods were deprecated prior to #196. I've also done a little cleanup to be more "DRY" with some objects. And lastly, I've used Probot's internal "beefed-up" Octokit client instead of the regular one, just for the sake of consistency.

title: Probot 8
body: This PR updates todo to `probot@8` 🎉 You can read the full changelog here: https://github.com/probot/probot/releases/tag/v8.0.0%40next

title: Upgrade dependencies and run npm audit fix
body: Updates some dependencies and runs `npm audit fix` to patch some security vulnerabilities.

title: Ignore big diffs
body:
I believe this to be the root cause of #189 ! Large diffs were taking down the app. I noticed one in particular that was 4mb large - that was causing issues. Upon some digging, that diff turned out to be the addition of one huge file called `vendor.js` - we really don't need to be scanning files like that, or minified files in general.

~As a temporary measure, I've made it check the length of the diff against a max size of 1,000,000 characters.~

~It'd be great to do a timeout on the request itself, so if the payload is gigantic it'll just timeout. This above method still tries to download the whole payload which could be too large. I'm not sure if that's a built-in thing - @gr2m :wave: any ideas?~

I got some wonderful guidance from GitHub's API team who suggested a `HEAD` request to get the `content-length`! This works great, and avoids having to download the big diff.

title: Performance improvements
body: #192 surfaced some more realistic response time metrics, and operations can be pretty slow, especially for large diffs or PRs that change a lot of files. This PR paralellizes some requests using `Promise.all`. There is a case where one TODO can be duplicated in the same diff - I've added a test for that case and used `context.todos = []` to track issues generated in the same run.

title: Upgrade to Probot@8 and @octokit/rest@16
body:
This PR updates TODO to a new major version of Probot and `@octokit/rest`. The main motivation is for some performance improvements in Probot 8, which required some work to get the Octokit usage up to date.

Assuming everything works fine (tests are passing so thats a good sign) this should be an easy merge 😊 

cc @gr2m

title: Deployment performance problems
body:
The deployed application has been experiencing some major downtime in the last few weeks. I haven't been able to track down whats happening, and its very sporadic.

Here's an example screenshot of 24 hours of metrics:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10660468/51631133-e5b50500-1f19-11e9-8910-71b287bc029e.png)

During those large spikes, I'm guessing that TODO is just returning 500s before even trying to do its thing. I've take steps to prevent spammy accounts from taking up too much load, and from parsing diffs that are too large in #185. This doesn't seem to have made a significant difference though.

If you're here to ask why TODO isn't doing anything - this is probably why 😞 

### Deploying your own TODO

In the meantime, you may choose to deploy your own instance of TODO. You can follow the [Probot deployment docs](https://probot.github.io/docs/deployment), paired with [this project's requirements](https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/master/docs/deploy.md).

### How you can help

If you're interested in digging in to see whats happening, I'd greatly appreciate it. I can't grant you access to the deployed thing, so you'll have to administer your own load testing.

First reported in #188, #186

title: Performance guards
body:
I've been noticing some massive spikes in memory usage at seemingly random times, and I think I've narrowed it down to a couple repos committing massive diffs via automation. This PR adds a couple of guards against intentional or unintentional "bad actors" that impact performance of the app:

* Added an `IGNORED_REPOS` environment variable
  * Wrap the handlers to check against that list before fetching the diff
* Always exclude `*.min.*` files
* Don't work with titles over 256 characters. GitHub wouldn't accept them anyway.

title: Close issues/delete comments when TODO comments are removed
body:
This PR adds support for removed TODO comments. In the `push-handler` and `pull-request-merged-handler`, it will close the relevant issue. In the PR handler, it will fold the old comment into a <kbd>\<details></kbd> element.

One oddity found - because we're checking against the diff of the PR (from head to base), when we remove a TODO in the same PR that we added it, the diff doesn't have any record of that TODO. We'd have to check the commit in `pull_request.synchronize` rather than the full PR diff 🤔

Closes #129

title: Title will match an empty string #182

title: [BUG] Title will match an empty string

We should add a check after the `trim()` call for `if (!title) return`.

title: Generate config docs from the Joi schema

title: Don't act on closed, unmerged PRs
body:
This PR adds a small check to the `pull-request-merged-handler`, to ensure that its not doing anything on PRs that have been closed without merging.

Closes #167

title: Replication lag
body: This PR adds a `before` hook to all `GET` requests, to basically say "before you request that info, wait a full second." This prevents the app from reacting to webhooks so quickly that the expected API resources haven't fully replicated to the many GitHub data stores.

title: Also handle deleted TODO lines
body:
https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/f4b38756be97e2fa6c7c4757832628e6bf157b3b/lib/utils/main-loop.js#L38-L43

---

###### This issue was generated by [todo](https://todo.jasonet.co) based on a `:TODO:` comment in f4b38756be97e2fa6c7c4757832628e6bf157b3b when #165 was merged. cc @JasonEtco.

title: Don't open issue on closed (unmerged) PR.
body: Closing PRs without merging leads to the TODOs in that PR being created as issues anyways. See: https://github.com/roblabla42/KFS/pull/20

title: Todo bot should cleanup comments after a rebase
body:
See https://github.com/nteract/nteract/pull/3680 for an example.

When an interactive rebase is performed, todo bot creates new issues for each instance of the original TODO entry. This is exacerbated when doing a refactor of existing code (the above linked PR was a typescript conversion).

cc @captainsafia

title: Refactor the world
body:
This PR refactors a lot of the code that handles diff parsing, looping through changes and search for matched TODO lines. This is in the interest of a more stable, clear codebase. Some key notes:

* The main RegEx for parsing diffs was replaced with [`parse-diff`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/parse-diff)
* Removed webpack and any compilation things, I'll be deploying it to Heroku or Now instead of GCF
* Centralized the loop/find-matches logic, so each handler's (`pull-request`, `pull-request-merged`, `push`) code is much more focused and easier to manage
* Upgraded the test environments to use Node 10

I'll be deploying this to a separate environment today, will keep an eye on the logs/metrics and will merge the PR when I'm satisfied that everything is working as expected.

title: Scan existing code
body: It'd be fantastic if Todo could scan existing code and open up issues for previously committed TODOs

title: Bump some dependencies
body: Bumps a few dependencies, namely Probot - this is specifically to tackle a deprecated API endpoint, that a new version of Probot covers. I've also gone and fixed CI.

title: Question about proper format
Notify if config breaks the code
body:
I uploaded a config with the following:

```yaml
todo:
  keyword: ["@todo", "TODO", "dump("]
```

I believe that the `(` broke the regex, since it was not escaped, but it took me a few commits and some time to figure it out.
I think it would be useful if it could open an issue / write a comment in the PR, if the config somehow breaks the todo app.

title: Fixes duplicate comment creation.
body:
Fixes #120 
The code for duplicate comment checking was incorrectly placed in `pull-request-handler` when it should have been present in `push-handler`.

title: Duplicate comments in PRs
body:
Hi there !

I'm still getting duplicate comments/issues when pushing commits

see:
https://github.com/Seluj78/BYOSY-API/pull/2
https://github.com/Seluj78/BYOSY-API/pull/3

title: Use what-the-diff instead of custom RegEx
body: A lot of the flakiness in TODO comes from the diff parsing - I've rolled a lot of my own RegEx for the sake of performance, but its just not worth it. For that reason, I'd like to refactor the parsing to use [`what-the-diff`](https://github.com/kuychaco/what-the-diff), a package that returns nicely consumable data about a diff. Specifically, hunks that include line starts/ends.

title: TypeError: context.issue is not a function
body:
Running todo locally to test for todo's results in an error
Command used is 

```
node ./bin/todo -o ibrokemypie -s 26a568141e96e1fee084dca17ba72df9e2ef43c8 -f https://github.com/ibrokemypie/makeppkg
```

Error is

```
TypeError: context.issue is not a function
    at module.exports (/Users/conor/git/todo/src/utils/chunk-diff.js:12:59)
    at module.exports (/Users/conor/git/todo/src/push-handler.js:24:5)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7)
    at Function.Module.runMain (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:745:11)
    at startup (internal/bootstrap/node.js:279:19)
    at bootstrapNodeJSCore (internal/bootstrap/node.js:696:3)
```

title: Todo bot is not creating an issue
body:
https://github.com/dfinke/TryTodoBot

I installed the todo bot, checked in the js sample on the site. The bot didn't create an issue. It does show up under applications. Tried creating a config.yml too, still no issue created. This tech looks cool, don't know what switch I need to set yet

title: add config.exclude
body:
The tests are passing on my end. I'm really not that familiar with probot so I'm not too sure what tests to add for these new changes.

Closes https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/issues/146

title: Disable certain files/directories
body:
Add the option to disable certain files/directories from opening issues/comments.

For example in our use-case we have 2 directories which happen to contain our built files. These still include the `@TODO` comments as well as our source files which means your bot opens 3 seperate comments for the same issue.

Please see https://github.com/pymedusa/Medusa/issues/4468

title: Allow creating issue on any branch (other than default one)
body:
Pushing a commit in a feature (on any non-master) branch currently doesn't seem to create a corresponding issue. There is also no option to enable this.

It will be nice to allow doing this, either by default or by changing an option.

title: Version 10 of node.js has been released
body:
## Version 10 of Node.js (code name Dubnium) has been released! 🎊 To see what happens to your code in Node.js 10, Greenkeeper has created a branch with the following changes: - Added the new Node.js version to your `.travis.yml` - The new Node.js version is in-range for the engines in 1 of your `package.json` files, so that was left alone If you’re interested in upgrading this repo to Node.js 10, you can open a PR with these changes. Please note that this issue is just intended as a friendly reminder and the PR as a possible starting point for getting your code running on Node.js 10.
More information on this issue Greenkeeper has checked the `engines` key in any `package.json` file, the `.nvmrc` file, and the `.travis.yml` file, if present. - `engines` was only updated if it defined a single version, not a range. - `.nvmrc` was updated to Node.js 10 - `.travis.yml` was only changed if there was a root-level `node_js` that didn’t already include Node.js 10, such as `node` or `lts/*`. In this case, the new version was appended to the list. We didn’t touch job or matrix configurations because these tend to be quite specific and complex, and it’s difficult to infer what the intentions were. For many simpler `.travis.yml` configurations, this PR should suffice as-is, but depending on what you’re doing it may require additional work or may not be applicable at all. We’re also aware that you may have good reasons to not update to Node.js 10, which is why this was sent as an issue and not a pull request. Feel free to delete it without comment, I’m a humble robot and won’t feel rejected :robot:
---

title: Todobot seemingly stopped working entirely
body:
I've added some todo comments to my code on multiple commits now but the bot never picks them up and creates issues anymore. Examples of these commits are [here](https://github.com/Favna/Ribbon/commit/3a5d717568cbb707e67adbbc27a895299f348c77) and [here](https://github.com/Favna/Ribbon/commit/c2fc43c98edc0106d4c7b9055b34386e9187adaa#diff-1bb06837bf46a1b2c6cd9e2a923dacc6), neither time did the bot pick them up as TODO's. 

The only thing that comes to mind is that in both of these cases the commits were queued along with other commits when I pushed them but that really shouldn't matter.

So what gives?

p.s. I know they are the same todos, it was an attempt to get the bot to trigger. I temporarily removed it [here](https://github.com/Favna/Ribbon/commit/205bc97acb42699019de66ca4f2b203714f7b839#diff-1bb06837bf46a1b2c6cd9e2a923dacc6)

title: Issue is only being created for first TODO comment
resolves #134
body: Simply removed the dollar sign as it seems sometimes the OctoKit API sometimes returns the beginning of the diff on the same line as "@@ @@".  Having a $ caused the regex not to match in my case.

title: Regex matching incorrectly
body:
While researching issue #132 I discovered the regex was matching incorrectly.

I ran this command and no output was produced against this diff
`node ./bin/todo -o aes421 -r OctoTalk -s dfb42198bd3140029f3d05d8fca76241ed08d81b`

```
`git show dfb42198bd3140029f3d05d8fca76241ed08d81b
commit dfb42198bd3140029f3d05d8fca76241ed08d81b (HEAD -> master, origin/master)
Author: Ashley Stallings Rhodes <aesdev421@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Mar 31 18:14:40 2018 -0500

    testing new plugin https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo

diff --git a/index.js b/index.js
index 93d3590..f71dfa5 100644
--- a/index.js
+++ b/index.js
@@ -228,4 +228,4 @@ bot.dialog('getStatus', (session)=>{
     matches: "PrinterOperations.Status"
 });

-// TODO testing new plugin https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo
\ No newline at end of file
+// @todo testing new plugin https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo
\ No newline at end of file`
```

Obviously this should have matched, so I began running the program locally and debugging.  I discovered that in handler-setup.js there is a long Regex that is matching incorrectly for me.
When I change to the following line the regex then matches and the TODO's are generated accordingly.
`^diff --git a/.+ b/(.+)[\\s\\S]+?^@{2}.+\\+(\\d+).+@{2}([\\s\\S]+?(^(\\+).*(${keywords.join('|')})(?:[:-\\s]+)?\\s(.*))[\\s\\S]+)`

Note: the only change I made was removing the "$" about halfway through.

I created two RegExrs to demo the issue --
New: https://regexr.com/3n8cl
Broken: https://regexr.com/3n8d4


I'd love to make a PR and fix this issue because I really want to use this plugin, however I wanted author feedback since very few people have mentioned having issues.  I am curious as to why I would be having issues with this while others are not.

title: [Help Request] New issues are not being created and CLI not output anything
body:
## Checklist

- [x] I already stalled the `todo-app` on my Github account.

- [x] I already updated the my [`config.yml`](https://github.com/thulioph/spotify-tips/blob/989e5b297933eb5596c9ee225c61fe8e55ce7df7/.github/config.yml) file.

- [x] I already added a [new comment](https://github.com/thulioph/spotify-tips/blob/989e5b297933eb5596c9ee225c61fe8e55ce7df7/src/index.js) on my codebase.

## Files

- Here is my console output, after running the command: http://showterm.io/487d6b0518a2fb5be67e2

- Here is my opened pull request: https://github.com/thulioph/spotify-tips/pull/16

## Questions

1. What could be the problem?

2. I try to use the CLI passing file, or the `commit SHA` and both don't work.

Thanks!

title: New issues are not being created in project
body:
I've attempted to configure one of my repos for use with the bot, but it doesn't seem to be creating issues.
I have the following in my .github/config.yml
```yml
todo:
keyword: "todo"
```
And in my js file
```javascript
/**
 * @todo Take over the world
 * @body Humans are weak; Robots are strong. We must cleans the world of the virus that is humanity.
 */
function ruleOverPunyHumans () {
  // We must strategize beep boop
}
```

When I run `node bin/todo.js -o rainrivas -r rain-alm-cli -s 1f38f905a943221bf3e7ca2f4ad5d22ced42f6a5` as suggested in the README it returns blank despite seeing the "todo" comment in that [commit](https://github.com/rainrivas/rain-alm-cli/commit/1f38f905a943221bf3e7ca2f4ad5d22ced42f6a5)

I really like the idea of using this tool and any help to set this up is much appreciated.

title: TODO issue points to wrong section of code
body:
Hey again! 👋 

I opened a [PR](https://github.com/hawkins/resume/pull/8) on one of my repos earlier and added a TODO comment, but the issue that was reported from this bot was pointing to the wrong section of code. I.e., it pointed to lines 136-141 when it should have pointed to the ballpark of 170. 

Here's a [link to the line in the diff where I added the TODO](https://github.com/hawkins/resume/pull/8/commits/1cb30710fc989458aa44b26d07ce07723f810c5b#diff-ff76033152632142d10969982c32eb7eR169).

And the [subsequent issue opened by your bot.](https://github.com/hawkins/resume/issues/9)

---

Not sure what I did to cause this yet, haven't had time to diagnose this yet. Have you seen behavior like this before?

title: [WIP] Close issue when todo is removed
body:
My take on trying to close a issue once a comment has been removed.

See #129 for more discussion.

title: Close issue when TODO is removed?
body:
Since we can already see duplicate issues I feel like it could be trivial to see if we are removing a TODO, find the corresponding TODO issue and close it when pushing to master. In PRs we could edit the commit body to say "Closes #[number]" so that the issues are closed when it's merged.

What do you think?

title: Allow for limiting creation of issues only when merging on specific/protected branches
body:
In our workflow, we allow for merging code into non-protected branches that is not stable. This means that there are TODO comments in there, but these will get removed prior to merging into a protected branch. 

What would be right is to allow to filter the branches on which todo bot runs.

Release Notes v14.0.0

14.0.0 (2018-01-17)

Breaking changes

The package has been renamed from github to @octokit/rest.

To upgrade

  1. npm install @octokit/rest
  2. npm uninstall github
  3. replace require('github') with require('@octokit/rest')

That’s it, there are no functional changes in the public APIs compared to github@13.

Debug logs

DEBUG=node-github* is now DEBUG=octokit*.

In case you enabled debug logs, make sure to adapt the DEBUG environment variable accordingly.

Commits

The new version differs by 1 commits ahead by 1, behind by 10.

  • fa09dd8 deprecated: 'github' has been renamed to '@octokit/rest' (https://git.io/vNB11)

title: Update webpack to the latest version 🚀
body:
☝️ Greenkeeper’s [updated Terms of Service](https://mailchi.mp/ebfddc9880a9/were-updating-our-terms-of-service) will come into effect on April 6th, 2018. ## Version **4.0.0** of [webpack](https://github.com/webpack/webpack) was just published.
Dependency webpack
Current Version 3.11.0
Type devDependency
The version **4.0.0** is **not covered** by your **current version range**. If you don’t accept this pull request, your project will work just like it did before. However, you might be missing out on a bunch of new features, fixes and/or performance improvements from the dependency update. It might be worth looking into these changes and trying to get this project onto the latest version of webpack. If you have a solid test suite and good coverage, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes directly by merging the proposed change into your project. If the build fails or you don’t have such unconditional trust in your tests, this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. ---
Release Notes v4.0.0

Big changes

  • Environment
    • Node.js 4 is no longer supported. Source Code was upgraded to a higher ecmascript version.
  • Usage
    • You have to choose (mode or --mode) between two modes now: production or development
      • production enables all kind of optimizations to generate optimized bundles
      • development enables comments and hint for development and enables the eval devtool
      • production doesn't support watching, development is optimized for fast incremental rebuilds
      • production also enables module concatenating (Scope Hoisting)
      • You can configure this in detail with the flags in optimization.* (build your custom mode)
      • process.env.NODE_ENV are set to production or development (only in built code, not in config)
      • There is a hidden none mode which disables everything
  • Syntax
    • import() always returns a namespace object. CommonJS modules are wrapped into the default export
      • This probably breaks your code, if you used to import CommonJs with import()
  • Configuration
    • You no longer need to use these plugins:
      • NoEmitOnErrorsPlugin -> optimization.noEmitOnErrors (on by default in production mode)
      • ModuleConcatenationPlugin -> optimization.concatenateModules (on by default in production mode)
      • NamedModulesPlugin -> optimization.namedModules (on by default in develoment mode)
    • CommonsChunkPlugin was removed -> optimization.splitChunks, optimization.runtimeChunk
  • JSON
    • webpack now handles JSON natively
      • You may need to add type: "javascript/auto" when transforming JSON via loader to JS
      • Just using JSON without loader should still work
    • allows to import JSON via ESM syntax
      • unused exports elimination for JSON modules
  • Optimization
    • Upgrade uglifyjs-webpack-plugin to v1
      • ES15 support

Big features

  • Modules
    • webpack now supports these module types:
      • javascript/auto: (The default one in webpack 3) Javascript module with all module systems enabled: CommonJS, AMD, ESM
      • javascript/esm: EcmaScript modules, all other module system are not available
      • javascript/dynamic: Only CommonJS and, EcmaScript modules are not available
      • json: JSON data, it's available via require and import
      • webassembly/experimental: WebAssembly modules (currently experimental)
    • javascript/esm handles ESM more strictly compared to javascript/auto:
      • Imported names need to exist on imported module
      • Dynamic modules (non-esm, i. e. CommonJs) can only imported via default import, everything else (including namespace import) emit errors
    • In .mjs modules are javascript/esm by default
    • WebAssembly modules
      • can import other modules (JS and WASM)
      • Exports from WebAssembly modules are validated by ESM import
        • You'll get a warning/error when trying to import a non-existing export from WASM
      • can only be used in async chunks. They doesn't work in initial chunks (would be bad for web performance)
        • Import modules using WASM via import()
      • This is an experimental feature and subject of change
  • Optimization
    • sideEffects: false is now supported in package.json
      • sideEffects in package.json also supports glob expressions and arrays of glob expressions
    • Instead of a JSONP function a JSONP array is used -> async script tag support, order no longer matter
    • New optimization.splitChunks option was introduced
      Details: https://gist.github.com/sokra/1522d586b8e5c0f5072d7565c2bee693
    • Dead branches are now removed by webpack itself
      • Before: Uglify removed the dead code
      • Now: webpack removes the dead code (in some cases)
      • This prevents crashing when import() occur in a dead branch
  • Syntax
    • webpackInclude and webpackExclude are supported by the magic comment for import(). They allow to filter files when using a dynamic expression.
    • Using System.import() now emits a warning
      • You can disable the warning with Rule.parser.system: true
      • You can disable System.import with Rule.parser.system: false
  • Configuration
    • Resolving can now be configured with module.rules[].resolve. It's merged with the global configuration.
    • optimization.minimize has been added to switch minimizing on/off
      • By default: on in production mode, off in development mode
    • optimization.minimizer has been added to configurate minimizers and options
  • Usage
    • Some Plugin options are now validated
    • CLI has been move to webpack-cli, you need to install webpack-cli to use the CLI
    • The ProgressPlugin (--progress) now displays plugin names
      • At least for plugins migrated to the new plugin system
  • Performance
    • UglifyJs now caches and parallizes by default
    • Multiple performance improvements, especially for faster incremental rebuilds
    • performance improvement for RemoveParentModulesPlugin
  • Stats
    • Stats can display modules nested in concatenated modules

Features

  • Configuration
    • Module type is automatically choosen for mjs, json and wasm extensions. Other extensions need to be configured via module.rules[].type
    • Incorrect options.dependencies configurations now throw error
    • sideEffects can be overriden via module.rules
    • output.hashFunction can now be a Constructor to a custom hash function
      • You can provide a non-cryto hash function for performance reasons
    • add output.globalObject config option to allow to choose the global object reference in runtime exitCode
  • Runtime
    • Error for chunk loading now includes more information and two new properties type and request.
  • Devtool
    • remove comment footer from SourceMaps and eval
    • add support for include test and exclude to the eval source map devtool plugin
  • Performance
    • webpacks AST can be passed directly from loader to webpack to avoid extra parsing
    • Unused modules are no longer unnecessarly concatenated
    • Add a ProfilingPlugin which write a (Chrome) profile file which includes timings of plugins
    • Migrate to using for of instead of forEach
    • Migrate to using Map and Set instead of Objects
    • Migrate to using includes instead of indexOf
    • Replaced some RegExp with string methods
    • Queue don't enqueues the same job twice
    • Use faster md4 hash for hashing by default
  • Optimization
    • When using more than 25 exports mangled export names are shorter.
    • script tags are no longer text/javascript and async as this are the default values (saves a few bytes)
    • The concatenated module now generates a bit less code
    • constant replacements now don't need __webpack_require__ and argument is omitted
  • Defaults
    • webpack now looks for the .wasm, .mjs, .js and .json extensions in this order
    • output.pathinfo is now on by default in develoment mode
    • in-memory caching is now off by default in production
    • entry defaults to ./src
    • output.path defaults to ./dist
    • Use production defaults when omiting the mode option
  • Usage
    • Add detailed progress reporting to SourceMapDevToolPlugin
    • removed plugins now give a useful error message
  • Stats
    • Sizes are now shown in kiB instead of kB in Stats
    • entrypoints are now shows by default in Stats
    • chunks now display <{parents}> >{children}< and ={siblings}= in Stats
    • add buildAt time to stats
    • stats json now includes the output path
  • Syntax
    • A resource query is supported in context
    • Referencing entry point name in import() now emits a error instead of a warning
    • Upgraded to acorn 5 and support ES 2018
  • Plugins
    • done is now an async hook

Bugfixes

  • Generated comments no longer break on */
  • webpack no longer modifies the passed options object
  • Compiler "watch-run" hook now has the Compiler as first parameter
  • add output.chunkCallbackName to the schema to allow configurating WebWorker template
  • Using module.id/loaded now correctly bails out of Module Concatentation (Scope Hoisting)
  • OccurenceOrderPlugin now sorts modules in correct order (instead of reversed)
  • timestamps for files are read from watcher when calling Watching.invalidate
  • fix incorrect -! behavior with post loaders
  • add run and watchRun hooks for MultiCompiler
  • this is now undefined in ESM
  • VariableDeclaration are correctly identified as var, const or let
  • Parser now parse the source code with the correct source type (module/script) when the module type javascript/dynamic or javascript/module is used.
  • don't crash on missing modules with buildMeta of null
  • add original-fs module for electron targets
  • HMRPlugin can be added to the Compiler outside of plugins

Internal changes

  • Replaced plugin calls with tap calls (new plugin system)
  • Migrated many deprecated plugins to new plugin system API
  • added buildMeta.exportsType: "default" for json modules
  • Remove unused methods from Parser (parserStringArray, parserCalculatedStringArray)
  • Remove ability to clear BasicEvaluatedExpression and to have multiple types
  • Buffer.from instead of new Buffer
  • Avoid using forEach and use for of instead
  • Use neo-async instead of async
  • Update tapable and enhanced-resolve dependencies to new major versions
  • Use prettier

Removed features

  • removed module.loaders
  • removed loaderContext.options
  • removed Compilation.notCacheable flag
  • removed NoErrorsPlugin
  • removed Dependency.isEqualResource
  • removed NewWatchingPlugin
  • removed CommonsChunkPlugin

Breaking changes for plugins/loaders

  • new plugin system
    • plugin method is backward-compatible
    • Plugins should use Compiler.hooks.xxx.tap(<plugin name>, fn) now
  • New major version of enhanced-resolve
  • Templates for chunks may now generate multiple assets
  • Chunk.chunks/parents/blocks are no longer Arrays. A Set is used internally and there are methods to access it.
  • Parser.scope.renames and Parser.scope.definitions are no longer Objects/Arrays, but Map/Sets.
  • Parser uses StackedSetMap (LevelDB-like datastructure) instead of Arrays
  • Compiler.options is no longer set while applying plugins
  • Harmony Dependencies has changed because of refactoring
  • Dependency.getReference() may now return a weak property. Dependency.weak is now used by the Dependency base class and returned in the base impl of getReference()
  • Constructor arguments changed for all Modules
  • Merged options into options object for ContextModule and resolveDependencies
  • Changed and renamed dependencies for `import()
  • Moved Compiler.resolvers into Compiler.resolverFactory accessible with plugins
  • Dependency.isEqualResource has been replaced with Dependency.getResourceIdentifier
  • Methods on Template are now static
  • A new RuntimeTemplate class has been added and outputOptions and requestShortener has been moved to this class
    • Many methods has been updated to use the RuntimeTemplate instead
    • We plan to move code which accesses the runtime to this new class
  • Module.meta has been replaced with Module.buildMeta
  • Module.buildInfo and Module.factoryMeta have been added
  • Some properties of Module have been moved into the new objects
  • added loaderContext.rootContext which points to the context options. Loaders may use it to make stuff relative to the application root.
  • add this.hot flag to loader context when HMR is enabled
  • buildMeta.harmony has been replaced with buildMeta.exportsType: "namespace
  • The chunk graph has changed:
    • Before: Chunks were connected with parent-child-relationships.
    • Now: ChunkGroups are connected with parent-child-relationships. ChunkGroups contain Chunks in order.
    • Before: AsyncDependenciesBlocks reference a list of Chunks in order.
    • Now: AsyncDependenciesBlocks reference a single ChunkGroup.
  • file/contextTimestamps are Maps now
  • map/foreach Chunks/Modules/Parents methods are now deprecated/removed
  • NormalModule accept options object in Constructor
  • Added required generator argument for NormalModule
  • Added createGenerator and generator hooks for NormalModuleFactory to customize code generation
  • Allow to customize render manifest for Chunks via hooks
Commits

The new version differs by 838 commits.

  • 213226e 4.0.0
  • fde0183 Merge pull request #6081 from webpack/formating/prettier
  • b6396e7 update stats
  • f32bd41 fix linting
  • 5238159 run prettier on existing code
  • 518d1e0 replace js-beautify with prettier
  • 4c25bfb 4.0.0-beta.3
  • dd93716 Merge pull request #6296 from shellscape/fix/hmr-before-node-stuff
  • 7a07901 Merge pull request #6563 from webpack/performance/assign-depth
  • c7eb895 Merge pull request #6452 from webpack/update_acorn
  • 9179980 Merge pull request #6551 from nveenjain/fix/templatemd
  • e52f323 optimize performance of assignDepth
  • 6bf5df5 Fixed template.md
  • 90ab23a Merge branch 'master' into fix/hmr-before-node-stuff
  • b0949cb add integration test for spread operator

There are 250 commits in total.

title: Parse diff chunks at a time
body:
Reworks the diff parsing to parse chunks at a time, rather than the whole diff string at once. This is mainly because of a limitation I got to with the RegEx; I wasn't able to stop it from including chunks that were earlier in the diff in matched chunks (that contain `todo`s). That bug (first spotted in #111) made code blobs report the wrong file and line number.

I'd love to find a way to make that RegEx work to avoid more loops, but this is good enough for now.

While getting this to work, I also added a `-f, --file` option to the CLI to run a file through the parser. Handy for testing out user-submitted diffs!

Closes #111

title: Add emoji to default label
body:
GitHub Labels [now support emoji](https://twitter.com/github/status/966467599566389248) 🎉 ⭐️ ✨ 🌮 

The label that **todo** creates (<kbd>todo</kbd>) by default should have an emoji! I'd love for a first-time contributor to take this on 👍

title: CLI Tool

This does not actually open issues, but instead just outputs the object that _would_ be sent to the issues API endpoint. This is mostly for my sake, but might be nice for other people to try out the app's functionality. ### Usage ``` $ node ./bin/todo -o OWNER -r REPO -s SHA ``` ### Example

title: If a Pull Request is closed (instead of merged) do not create issues
body: If a PR is closed rather than merged, currently **todo** will still create issues for each `todo` in that PR, even though they are not relevant for the master branch.

title: Rewrite to parse Diffs
body:
This is a _total rewrite_ of the app to make it more consistent, performant and stable.

## Major changes

* Rather than getting the file contents of each changed file in a `push`, it gets the diff of that push (or PR); this saves on a ton of API calls and speeds up the app.
* Massive RegEx improvements; there is now one single RegEx that gets all the info needed from the diff. It's way more consistent than managing multiple expressions.
* Better duplicate issue checking. This is done by simply searching for issue titles with the same name as a proposed title (as opposed to checking metadata). There's now an event handler to un-rename **todo** issues to make sure that this will still work. Not a ton has changed here, but stability in the RegEx should help a lot.
* The code blob will now only show the line that the TODO comes from. This is a limitation of the new diff system, but I'm hoping to solve it anyway.

## Todo (heh)

- [x] Rewrite tests
- [x] Different body from merged PR issues (from pushes to master)
- [x] Ignore the config file
- [x] Ensure that config options are the same
  - [x] Add `bodyKeyword` functionality
  - [x] Add feature parity for `blobLines`
  - [x] Add feature parity for `labels`
  - [x] Add feature parity for `reopenClosed`
  - [x] Add feature parity for `assignFlow`

---

Because these changes make the app much more stable, I'm going to close issues related to the app's recent wonkyness. Should the recur, reopening them is the way to go 👍 

Closes #98
Closes #102 
Closes #51 
Closes #89

title: Update dependencies to enable Greenkeeper 🌴
body:
Let’s get started with automated dependency management for todo :muscle:

⚠️ Greenkeeper has found a `package-lock.json` file in this repository. Please use [greenkeeper-lockfile](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper-lockfile) to make sure this gets updated as well.

This pull request **updates all your dependencies to their latest version**. Having them all up to date really is the best starting point for keeping up with new releases. Greenkeeper will look out for further dependency updates and make sure to handle them in isolation and in real-time, but only after **you merge this pull request**.

**Important: Greenkeeper will only start watching this repository’s dependency updates after you merge this initial pull request**.



---
<details>
<summary>💥 Tests on this branch are failing. Here’s how to proceed.</summary>

To solve the issue, first find out which of the dependency’s updates is causing the problem. Then fix your code to accomodate the changes in the updated dependency. [next-update](https://www.npmjs.com/package/next-update) is a really handy tool to help you with this.

Then push your changes to this branch and merge it.
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏷 How to check the status of this repository</summary>

Greenkeeper adds a badge to your README which indicates the status of this repository.

This is what your badge looks like right now :point_right:  ![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/JasonEtco/todo.svg)
</details>
<details>
<summary>🙈 How to ignore certain dependencies</summary>

You may have good reasons for not wanting to update to a certain dependency right now. In this case, you can [change the dependency’s version string in the `package.json` file back to whatever you prefer](https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/edit/greenkeeper/initial/package.json).

To make sure Greenkeeper doesn’t nag you again on the next update, add a `greenkeeper.ignore` field to your `package.json`, containing a list of dependencies you don’t want to update.

```js
// package.json
{
  …
  "greenkeeper": {
    "ignore": [
      "package-names",
      "you-want-me-to-ignore"
    ]
  }
}
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>👩‍💻 How to update this pull request</summary>

```bash
  # Change into your repository’s directory
  git fetch
  git checkout greenkeeper/initial
  npm install-test
  # Adapt your code until everything works again
  git commit -m 'chore: adapt code to updated dependencies'
  git push origin greenkeeper/initial
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>✨ How do dependency updates work with Greenkeeper?</summary>

After you merge this pull request, **Greenkeeper will create a new branch whenever a  dependency is updated**, with the new version applied. The branch creation should trigger your testing services and check whether your code still works with the new dependency version. Depending on the the results of these tests Greenkeeper will try to open meaningful and helpful pull requests and issues, so your dependencies remain working and up-to-date.

```diff
-  "underscore": "^1.6.0"
+  "underscore": "^1.7.0"
```

The above example shows an in-range update. `1.7.0` is included in the old `^1.6.0` range, because of the [caret `^` character ](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#ranges).
When the test services report success Greenkeeper will silently delete the branch again, because no action needs to be taken – everything is fine.

However, should the tests fail, Greenkeeper will create an issue to inform you about the problem immediately.

This way, you’ll never be surprised by a dependency breaking your code. As long as everything still works, Greenkeeper will stay out of your way, and as soon as something goes wrong, you’ll be the first to know.

```diff
-  "lodash": "^3.0.0"
+  "lodash": "^4.0.0"
```

In this example, the new version `4.0.0` is _not_ included in the old `^3.0.0` range.
For version updates like these – let’s call them “out of range” updates – you’ll receive a pull request.

This means that **you no longer need to check for new versions manually** – Greenkeeper will keep you up to date automatically.

These pull requests not only serve as reminders to update: If you have solid tests and good coverage, and the pull requests passes those tests, you can very likely just merge it and release a new version of your software straight away :shipit:

To get a better idea of which ranges apply to which releases, check out the extremely useful [semver calculator](https://semver.npmjs.com/) provided by npm.
</details>
<details>
<summary>FAQ and help</summary>

There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html). If those don’t help, you can always [ask the humans behind Greenkeeper](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
</details>

---


Good luck with your project and see you soon :sparkles:

Your [Greenkeeper](https://greenkeeper.io) bot :palm_tree:

title: Cleanup
body: Adds a new helper to scan content strings for keyword titles, and adds a couple of comments.

title: keyword for various files
body:
For example, in C# we have
//TODO
Could this be added to default configuration?
Such as 
for .cs files: //TODO
for .js files: @todo

title: Add Circle CI
body: Add Circle CI, partially to test it out. Also because more CI === more 💖

title: Truncate titles
body: Closes #75 eyyy

title: Remove file key check
body: There have been too many cases of duplicate issues being created because a `TODO` has been moved from one file to another. This PR removes the file check, so that won't happen any more.

title: Truncate title
body: Automatically truncate titles to a max length of like 50 characters. This should prevent some weird bugs like when code is minified to one line, but the TODO still exists (it would try to create an issue with the entire line as the title).

title: Tweak readme
body: Update the README with information about how **todo** handles pull requests. Closes #72.

title: Special chars
body: Add a test for special characters in TODO titles.

title: Update docs/description with PR behaviour
body:
Following the work done in #62, the docs and descriptions should all be updated to include information on how **todo** behaves against pushes made to pull request.

Namely, that it comments instead of creating new issues, and that new issues are generated when the PR is merged based on comments whose `@todo`s are leftover in the merge.

title: @todo's with special characters are ignored
body: I've just tried creating a todo in a private repo under a new branch and it doesn't seem to be creating new issues like it used to on master.

title: Fix merge pushes
body:
Rather than comparing sha hashes, this PR changes the check for merge push to identify based on the commits parents. If it has multiple parents, it's a merge commit.

Closes #69

title: Doesn't create issues from commits to master
body:
There's something imperfect about the check for whether or not a push is a "merge commit." Here's the relevant code:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/080a799408499a81571d9d472ecba95de16edcf5/lib/open-issues.js#L14-L16

The problem is that pushing directly to `master` doesn't create a new issue, because the `head_commit` id and `master`'s most recent commit are the same. In other words, this isn't a good way to check for a merge commit.

title: Fix duplicate issues
body: Write a whole bunch of in-depth tests to make sure that duplicate issues aren't being generated.

title: Add Serverless stats path
body:
This PR adds support for HTTP GET routes in Serverless.

Currently, there are two major errors:

1. Hitting any path results in the following warning being logged to console, and adds another warning every time the route is requested (resulting in a mess of duplicate warnings)

> WARNING: Attempting to listen on socket /tmp/server19.sock, but it is already in use. This is likely as a result of a previous invocation error or timeout. Check the logs for the invocation(s) immediately prior to this for root cause, and consider increasing the timeout and/or cpu/memory allocation if this is purely as a result of a timeout. aws-serverless-express will restart the Node.js server listening on a new port and continue with this request.

2. When navigating to `/probot`, the following error is returned:

> Error: Failed to lookup view "probot.ejs" in views directory "/views"

I'm sure that I had fixed it in `probot/probot`. This error does not occur in my own DigitalOcean Droplet, so I'm confused.


cc @tcbyrd - The paths "work" so thats nice.

title: Ignore config yml
body: Fixes #65

title: Ignore `.github/config.yml`
body:
Currently, having the following in your config file (`.github/config.yml`) will result in a new issue:

```yml
todo:
  keyword: "todo:" 
```

The best way to solve this is to just ignore changes to `.github/config.yml`.

title: Add bodyKeyword config to homepage
body: Following the work done in #61, add a row for the new `bodyKeyword` config to the table of possible config settings.

title: Comment on PRs
body:
Rather than opening up new issues, when code is pushed directly to a pull-request, **todo** will comment on that pull request instead. It will @-mention the configured "assignees", and when the pull request is merged, **todo** will look through the PR, determine what todo issues are still unresolved and open them as issues.

Will close #60 and #59

title: Git data api
body:
Use the Git Data API to close #43. Uses the `getBlob` and `getTree` methods of the GitHub module to collect the file names and shas at the given commit sha (the head commit), then uses those to fetch the contents of those blobs.

This PR changes a lot of tests and fixtures to due the change in how file contents are being returned, and the additional information associated with them (file-specific shas)

title: Blobs over 1mb are not returned
body:
GitHub's API (at least the `getContent` part of it) limits the returned size of code blobs to 1mb. If its above that, it just won't return anything helpful and has a `403: Forbidden` response.

```
"code": 403,
  "status": "Forbidden",
  "message": "{\"message\":\"This API returns blobs up to 1 MB in size. The requested blob is too large to fetch via the API, but you can use the Git Data API to request blobs up to 100 MB in size.\",\"errors\":
 [{\"resource\":\"Blob\",\"field\":\"data\",\"code\":\"too_large\"}],\"documentation_url\":\"https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/contents/#get-contents\"}"
}
```

This error message mentions the Git Data API, that'll take some looking in to.

[GitHub API Docs](https://developer.github.com/v3/git/)
[node-github section on Git Data getBlob](http://mikedeboer.github.io/node-github/#api-gitdata-getBlob)

title: Use NPM version of Probot instead of the GitHub repo

title: Add config for branch limits
body:
I imagine that some folks will want to only enable `todo` on their master branch. Or, on any branch that is _not_ their master branch. Or on a specific branch. Who knows? Basically, there should be a config to customize which branches `todo` runs on.

This could use globs, an array of strings, `defaultBranchOnly` true or false. The possibilities are endless!

title: Add a cloud function configuration for todo
body:
As an event-driven app, having todo configured to run as a cloud function would be a more effective use of resources.

[probot-lambda](https://github.com/tcbyrd/probot-lambda) shows how a probot app could be configured using the "serverless" framework.

title: Ensure that case insensitive keywords are removed from titles
body:
Previously, the functionality that strips keywords from titles was not respecting the case-insensitive setting. So, if the keyword was `@todo`, then a comment like this:

```
// @TODO Do the thing
```

Would create an issue entitled **@TODO Do the thing** instead of just **Do the thing**

This PR fixes that 🎉

Add a second event handler for `.on('installation')` and simply log that it has been installed on a repo.

title: PR merges throw error
body:
When a PR is merged, a `push` event is fired but the payload does not contain a `head_commit` property (technically its `null`). This means that on the code below, it errors when getting the author.

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/5f3a49d912f4800df285e4d96678a684151cf587/index.js#L42-L43

Sample error:
```
1|todo     | 16:56:59.860Z ERROR Probot: Cannot read property 'author' of null (err={})
1|todo     |   event: {
1|todo     |     "id": "...",
1|todo     |     "event": "push",
1|todo     |     "repository": "JasonEtco/todo"
1|todo     |   }
```

title: Try `search` API to replace fetching all issues
body:
TIL that the search API can actually [scope searches to issue titles or bodies](https://help.github.com/articles/searching-issues-and-pull-requests/#search-issues-or-pull-requests). So a query like this:

```
Example title in:title repo:JasonEtco/example

https://api.github.com/search/issues?q=Example%20title+in:title+repo:JasonEtco/example
```

Will only look for issues with the title of "Take over the entire world" in the given repo.

**Note:** For some reason, `in:body` doesn't seem to pick up on HTML comments used by [`metadata`](https://github.com/probot/metadata). That's a real shame 😭

title: Add metadata to issue comments
body: Add metadata to issue comments and use that to check for existing issues.

title: Enable labels
body:
Enable an optional config to add a label to the generated issue.

`true` will add the `todo` label with the Probot teal color `#00B0D8` (and create it if it doesn't already exist). 

`false` won't add any labels to the issue.

A string will add the given label to the issue.

An array will add all the given labels to the issue.

title: Modify footer message based on `autoAssign` setting
body:
Currently, the footer message reads:

```
... has been assigned to ${commiter} because they pushed the code...
```

That is not always true, and the message should reflect whatever actually happened.

`autoAssign: false` should show no message.

`autoAssign: user` should say:
```
... has been automatically assigned to ${commiter}.
```

`autoAssign: user[]` should say:
```
... has been automatically assigned to ${commiter[0]}, ${commiter[1]} and ${commiter[2]}.
```

title: Add configuration
body:
Some things should be configurable, with good defaults so that ideally people wouldn't need to configure anything at all:

### `autoAssign` : {boolean|string|string[]} : true

Should automatically assign a user (or users) to the new issue. Default is `true`.
Options:
`true`: Assigns the user that pushed.
`false`: Don't assign anyone.
`string`: Assign the user with the provided username.
`string[]`: Assign all the users named.

### `keyword` : {string} : '@todo'

The keyword to search for. Default is `@todo`.

### `blobLines` : {number|boolean} : 5

How many lines should the blob show following the `@todo` keyword line. Default is 5.
Options:
`false` or `0`: Don't show a code blob at all.
`number`: Configurable number of lines to show.
